title: King's College Criteria for Acetaminophen Toxicity
description: Determines need for liver transplant referral in patients with acute liver failure secondary to acetaminophen overdose. Used to identify patients with poor prognosis who may require urgent liver transplantation.

parameters.name: arterial_ph
parameters.description: Arterial pH value from arterial blood gas

parameters.name: inr
parameters.description: International Normalized Ratio (INR) for coagulation assessment

options.label: Grade I
options.description: Mild confusion, euphoria, depression, decreased attention

options.label: Grade II
options.description: Lethargy, moderate confusion, slurred speech, inappropriate behavior

options.label: Grade III
options.description: Marked confusion, incoherent speech, sleeping but rousable

parameters.name: phosphate
parameters.description: Serum phosphate level at 48-96 hours (additional prognostic marker)

result.name: kings_college_result
result.description: King's College Criteria assessment for liver transplant need

interpretation.criteria_met: Meets King's College Criteria - indicates poor prognosis and need for urgent liver transplant evaluation
interpretation.criteria_not_met: Does not meet King's College Criteria - but close monitoring still required as criteria are specific but not sensitive

references: O'Grady JG, Alexander GJ, Hayllar KM, Williams R. Early indicators of prognosis in fulminant hepatic failure. Gastroenterology. 1989 Aug;97(2):439-45.

Bailey B, Amre DK, Gaudreault P. Fulminant hepatic failure secondary to acetaminophen poisoning: a systematic review and meta-analysis of prognostic criteria determining the need for liver transplantation. Crit Care Med. 2003 Jan;31(1):299-305.
Bernal W, Auzinger G, Dhawan A, Wendon J. Acute liver failure. Lancet. 2010 Jul 17;376(9736):190-201.

Larson AM, Polson J, Fontana RJ, Davern TJ, Lalani E, Hynan LS, et al. Acetaminophen-induced acute liver failure: results of a United States multicenter, prospective study. Hepatology. 2005 Dec;42(6):1364-72.
formula: Meets criteria if: Arterial pH <7.30 OR (INR >6.5 AND Creatinine >3.4 mg/dL AND Hepatic Encephalopathy Grade III/IV)
notes: Developed to identify patients with acetaminophen-induced liver failure who need liver transplant evaluation
High specificity (95%) but moderate sensitivity (58%) - meeting criteria indicates poor prognosis
Not meeting criteria does not guarantee good outcome - close monitoring still required
Additional poor prognostic factors: lactate >3.5 mmol/L (early) or >3.0 mmol/L (full resuscitation), phosphate >3.75 mg/dL at 48-96h
Should prompt immediate referral to liver transplant center if criteria met
Developed before routine use of N-acetylcysteine - prognosis may be better with modern therapy
PT values may not be comparable across laboratories - INR preferred
Serial assessment may be more valuable than single timepoint
Consider other causes of acute liver failure if acetaminophen toxicity unclear
